intro: Bothriochloa barbinodis var. perforata, commonly known as the perforate barnyard grass, is a perennial grass species native to tropical and subtropical regions. It is characterized by its slender, erect stems and narrow, blade-like leaves with a rough texture. The plant produces small, spike-like inflorescences that bear numerous tiny, pale green to brown flowers. Its leaves have distinctive translucent nodes and often exhibit a perforated appearance along the midrib, giving it its common name. This grass is often found in disturbed soils and can be a problematic weed in agricultural fields.
